006
007package renderer.models_T;
008
009import renderer.scene.*;
010import renderer.scene.primitives.*;
011import renderer.scene.util.MeshMaker;
012
013/**
014   Create a solid model of a partial torus.
015<p>
016   See <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torus" target="_top">
017                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torus</a>
018<p>
019   This partial torus is the surface of revolution generated by revolving
020   a sector of the circle in the xy-plane with radius {@code r2} and center
021   {@code (r1,0,0)} part way around the y-axis. We are assuming that
022   {@code r1 > r2}.
023<p>
024   The whole torus is the surface of revolution generated by revolving
025   the whole circle in the xy-plane with radius {@code r2} and center
026   {@code (r1,0,0)} all the way around the y-axis.
027<p>
028   Here are parametric equations for the circle in the xy-plane with
029   radius {@code r2} and center {@code (r1,0,0)} and parameterized
030   starting from the top, with parameter {@code 0 <= phi <= 2*PI}.
031   <pre>{@code
032      x(phi) = r1 + r2 * sin(phi)
033      y(phi) =      r2 * cos(phi)
034      z(phi) = 0
035   }</pre>
036   Here is the 3D rotation matrix that rotates around the y-axis
037   by {@code theta} radians with {@code 0 <= theta <= 2*PI}.
038   <pre>{@code
039      [ cos(theta)   0   sin(theta)]
040      [     0        1       0     ]
041      [-sin(theta)   0   cos(theta)]
042   }</pre>
043   If we multiply the rotation matrix with the circle parameterization,
044   we get a parameterization of the torus.
045   <pre>{@code
046      [ cos(theta)   0   sin(theta)]   [r1 + r2 * sin(phi)]
047      [     0        1       0     ] * [     r2 * cos(phi)]
048      [-sin(theta)   0   cos(theta)]   [        0         ]
049
050      = ( r1*cos(theta) + r2*cos(theta)*sin(phi).
051          r2*cos(phi),
052         -r1*sin(theta) - r2*sin(theta)*sin(phi) )
053
054      = ( (r1 + r2*sin(phi)) * cos(theta),
055                r2*cos(phi),
056         -(r1 + r2*sin(phi)) * sin(theta) )
057   }</pre>
058   See
059     <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torus#Geometry" target="_top">
060              http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torus#Geometry</a>
061
062   @see Torus
063   @see CircleSector
064   @see DiskSector
065   @see RingSector
066   @see ConeSector
067   @see CylinderSector
068   @see SphereSector
069*/
070public class TorusSector extends Model implements MeshMaker
071{
072   public final double r1;
073   public final double r2;
074   public final double theta1;
075   public final double theta2;
076   public final double phi1;
077   public final double phi2;
078   public final int n;
079   public final int k;
080
081   /**
082      Create a partial torus with half the circle of revolution with radius 3/4
083      and a cross section that is half the circle of longitude with radius 1/4.
084   */
085   public TorusSector( )
086   {
087      this(0.75, 0.25, Math.PI/2, 3*Math.PI/2, Math.PI, 2*Math.PI, 6, 8);
088   }
089
090
091   /**
092      Create a partial torus with a partial circle of revolution
093      with radius {@code r1} and a cross section circle (circle of
094      longitude) with radius {@code r2}.
095   <p>
096      If {@code theta1 > 0} or {@code theta2 < 2*PI}, then the (partial)
097      circle of revolution is the circular sector from angle {@code theta1}
098      to angle {@code theta2}. In other words, the (partial) circles of
099      latitude in the model extend from angle {@code theta1} to angle
100      {@code theta2}.
101   <p>
102      The last two parameters determine the number of circles of longitude
103      and the number of (partial) circles of latitude in the model.
104   <p>
105      If there are {@code k} circles of longitude, then each (partial)
106      circle of latitude will have {@code k-1} line segments.
107      If there are {@code n} (partial) circles of latitude, then each
108      circle of longitude will have {@code n} line segments.
109   <p>
110      There must be at least four circles of longitude and at least
111      three circles of latitude.
112
113      @param r1      radius of the circle of revolution
114      @param r2      radius of the cross section circle (circle of longitude)
115      @param theta1  beginning longitude angle for the circle of revolution
116      @param theta2  ending longitude angle for the circle of revolution
117      @param n       number of circles of latitude
118      @param k       number of circles of longitude
119      @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code n} is less than 4
120      @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code k} is less than 4
121   */
122   public TorusSector(final double r1, final double r2,
123                      final double theta1, final double theta2,
124                      final int n, final int k)
125   {
126      this(r1, r2, theta1, theta2, 0, 2*Math.PI, n+1, k);
127   }
128
129
130   /**
131      Create a partial torus with a partial circle of revolution with
132      radius {@code r1} and a partial cross section circle with radius
133      {@code r2}.
134   <p>
135      If {@code phi1 > 0} or {@code phi2 < 2*PI}, then the (partial) cross
136      section circle is the circular sector from angle {@code phi1} to angle
137      {@code phi2}. In other words, the (partial) circles of longitude in the
138      model extend from angle {@code phi1} to angle {@code phi2}.
139   <p>
140      If {@code theta1 > 0} or {@code theta2 < 2*PI}, then the (partial) circle
141      of revolution is the circular sector from angle {@code theta1} to angle
142      {@code theta2}. In other words, the (partial) circles of latitude in
143      the model extend from angle {@code theta1} to angle {@code theta2}.
144   <p>
145      The last two parameters determine the number of (partial) circles of
146      longitude and the number of (partial) circles of latitude in the model.
147   <p>
148      If there are {@code k} circles of longitude, then each (partial)
149      circle of latitude will have {@code k-1} line segments.
150      If there are {@code n} (partial) circles of latitude, then each
151      circle of longitude will have {@code n-1} line segments.
152   <p>
153      There must be at least four circles of longitude and at least
154      four circles of latitude.
155
156      @param r1      radius of the circle of revolution
157      @param r2      radius of the cross section circle (circle of longitude)
158      @param theta1  beginning longitude angle for the circle of revolution
159      @param theta2  ending longitude angle for the circle of revolution
160      @param phi1    beginning latitude angle for the cross section circle
161      @param phi2    ending latitude angle for the cross section circle
162      @param n       number of circles of latitude
163      @param k       number of circles of longitude
164      @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code n} is less than 4
165      @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code k} is less than 4
166   */
167   public TorusSector(final double r1,     final double r2,
168                      final double theta1, final double theta2,
169                      final double phi1,   final double phi2,
170                      final int n, final int k)
171   {
172      super(String.format("Torus Sector(%.2f,%.2f,%.2f,%.2f,%.2f,%.2f,%d,%d)",
173                           r1, r2, theta1, theta2, phi1, phi2, n, k));
174
175      if (n < 4)
176         throw new IllegalArgumentException("n must be greater than 3");
177      if (k < 4)
178         throw new IllegalArgumentException("k must be greater than 3");
179
180      this.r1 = r1;
181      this.r2 = r2;
182      this.theta1 = theta1;
183      this.theta2 = theta2;
184      this.phi1 = phi1;
185      this.phi2 = phi2;
186      this.n = n;
187      this.k = k;
188
189      // Create the torus's geometry.
190
191      final double deltaPhi = (phi2 - phi1) / (n - 1),
192                   deltaTheta = (theta2 - theta1) / (k - 1);
193
194      // An array of vertices to be used to create triangles.
195      final Vertex[][] v = new Vertex[n][k];
196
197      // Create all the vertices.
198      for (int j = 0; j < k; ++j) // choose a rotation around the y-axis
199      {
200         final double c1 = Math.cos(theta1 + j * deltaTheta),
201                      s1 = Math.sin(theta1 + j * deltaTheta);
202         for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i)  // go around a cross section circle
203         {
204            final double c2 = Math.cos(phi1 + i * deltaPhi),
205                         s2 = Math.sin(phi1 + i * deltaPhi);
206            v[i][j] = new Vertex( (r1 + r2*s2) * c1,
207                                        r2*c2,
208                                 -(r1 + r2*s2) * s1 );
209         }
210      }
211
212      // Add all of the vertices to this model.
213      for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i)
214      {
215         for (int j = 0; j < k; ++j)
216         {
217            addVertex( v[i][j] );
218         }
219      }
220
221      // Create all the triangle strips.
222      for (int i = 0; i < n - 1; ++i)
223      {
224         for (int j = 0; j < k - 1; ++j)
225         {  //                         v[i][j] v[i+1][j]  v[i+1][j+1]
226            addPrimitive(new Triangle(i*k+j, (i+1)*k+j, (i+1)*k+j+1));
227            //                        v[i+1][j+1]  v[i][j+1] v[i][j]
228            addPrimitive(new Triangle((i+1)*k+j+1, i*k+j+1,  i*k+j));
229         }
230      }
231   }
232
233
234
235   // Implement the MeshMaker interface (three methods).
236   @Override public int getHorzCount() {return n;}
237
238   @Override public int getVertCount() {return k;}
239
240   @Override
241   public TorusSector remake(final int n, final int k)
242   {
243      return new TorusSector(this.r1,     this.r2,
244                             this.theta1, this.theta2,
245                             this.phi1,   this.phi2,
246                             n, k);
247   }
248}//TorusSector
